content:
Let sSet\mathbf{sSet}sSet be the category of simplicial sets and Graph\mathbf{Graph}Graph the category of directed multigraphs with morphisms as in Kerodon.001J. There is a functor F ⁣:sSet→GraphF\colon \mathbf{sSet}\to\mathbf{Graph}F:sSet→Graph, which associates to every simplicial set the graph whose vertices are the 0-simplices and whose edges are the nondegenerate 1-simplices. Does FFF have a left or right adjoint?

FFF restricts to an equivalence sSet≤1→Graph\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}\to\mathbf{Graph}sSet≤1​→Graph, hence one gets a functor Graph→sSet≤1\mathbf{Graph}\to \mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}Graph→sSet≤1​. I suspect that the composition Graph→sSet≤1→sSet\mathbf{Graph}\to \mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}\to\mathbf{sSet}Graph→sSet≤1​→sSet is a left adjoint of FFF.
yup
I guess it depends on what functor you mean by sSet≤1→sSetsSet_{\leq 1} \to sSetsSet≤1​→sSet
The forgetful functor sSet→sSet≤1sSet \to sSet_{\leq 1}sSet→sSet≤1​ has a left adjoint (the inclusion of 1-skeletal simpicial sets) and a right adjoint (the inclusion of 1-coskeletal simplicial sets)
there's a bit about that on the nlab
The left adjoint and (equivalently) the right adjoint are both fully faithful
Oh -- one subtlety
sSet≤1sSet_{\leq 1}sSet≤1​ is equivalent to the category of reflexive directed graphs
https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/reflexive+graph

I suppose the forgetful functor from simplicial sets to directed graphs not assumed to be reflexive still has left and right adjoints (given as before by left and right Kan extension) but they are no longer fully faithful
the left adjoint will take a graph and freely add a "degenerate" loop to each point.
Thanks!

Why do you call sSet→sSet≤1\mathbf{sSet}\to \mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}sSet→sSet≤1​ "forgetful"? I would call its left adjoint sSet≤1→sSet\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}\to\mathbf{sSet}sSet≤1​→sSet forgetful, because it forgets the fact that a simplicial set of dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1 has dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1.

Also, the nLab calls the functor sSet≤1→sSet\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}\to\mathbf{sSet}sSet≤1​→sSet "1-skeleton", sk1\mathrm{sk}_1sk1​. Lurie calls the right adjoint of that functor the "1-skeleton", sk1\mathrm{sk}_1sk1​.

Using the information you gave, to conclude, I would answer my question "Does FFF have a left or right adjoint?" with "yes, both", because F ⁣:sSet→GraphF\colon\mathbf {sSet}\to\mathbf{Graph}F:sSet→Graph factors as sSet→sSet≤1→Graph\mathbf{sSet}\to\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}\to\mathbf{Graph}sSet→sSet≤1​→Graph, where the first functor has both a left adjoint and a right adjoint, as you pointed out, and the second functor is an equivalence. Hence, by composition, one can get both a left and a right adjoint of F ⁣:sSet→GraphF\colon\mathbf {sSet}\to\mathbf{Graph}F:sSet→Graph.

Tim Campion said:

sSet≤1sSet_{\leq 1}sSet≤1​ is equivalent to the category of reflexive directed graphs

Mhm, here it says that the category of simplicial sets of dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1 is equivalent to the category of directed multigraphs, without restricting to reflexive graphs.

But one has to define the morphisms between graphs as in Kerodon.001J. So maybe if one doesn't want to define morphisms in that way one has to work with reflexive graphs?

Leopold Schlicht said:

Why do you call sSet→sSet≤1\mathbf{sSet}\to \mathbf{sSet}_{\leq 1}sSet→sSet≤1​ "forgetful"?

It forgets all of the (non-degenerate) simplices of dimension >1. As is typical for forgetful functors, this represents a loss of information, whereas the adjoints give canonical ways of extending the information of a graph to a simplicial set.

I'm not convinced. Every functor represents a loss of information (at least one can't create information), otherwise one wouldn't be able to specify for each object in the domain category an object of the codomain category.

Usually I think a functor needs to be faithful to be called "forgetful" or "underlying". For instance, I think people would consider it weird if one speaks about the "underlying preorder of a category", even though the preorder associated to a category contains less information than the category.

Whether a forgetful functor is faithful depends on what sort of stuff you forget. In this case, we normally think of a simplicial set XXX as a collection of sets X0X_0X0​, X1X_1X1​, X2X_2X2​, ... with a whole bunch of maps between them (satisfying some relations). The way we obtain the 1-skeleton is to "remember" X0X_0X0​ and X1X_1X1​ and the maps between them, and "forget" everything else. The fact that we're forgetting entire sets X2X_2X2​, X3X_3X3​, ... is what makes the forgetful functor turn out to not be faithful, but it's still forgetful in the ordinary informal sense.

Which functor is "forgetful" is very much a matter of convention though. There seem to be two conventions which sometimes conflict: use the one that (ironically) forgets least (the fully faithful one, or faithful if there isn't one); and, use the one that is closest to the middle of the adjoint string, breaking ties toward the right.

Leopold Schlicht said:

Tim Campion said:

sSet≤1sSet_{\leq 1}sSet≤1​ is equivalent to the category of reflexive directed graphs

Mhm, here it says that the category of simplicial sets of dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1 is equivalent to the category of directed multigraphs, without restricting to reflexive graphs.

But one has to define the morphisms between graphs as in Kerodon.001J. So maybe if one doesn't want to define morphisms in that way one has to work with reflexive graphs?

Yes, it looks like their nasty definition of "morphism between graphs" is the price they pay for not working with reflexive graphs.

In the ordinary category of directed multigraphs, with the usual kind of morphisms, the terminal object has three subobjects. In the category of reflexive graphs it just has two. If you have the patience to sort through Kerodon's nasty definition of morphism, you can see how it works with that.

In the ordinary category of directed multigraphs, which category theorists simply call "graphs", the terminal object is a vertex with an edge from itself to itself. This has three subobjects: itself, the vertex with no edge, and the empty graph.
In the category of reflexive graphs, the terminal object looks the same, but its only subobjects are itself and the empty graph.
In the category sSet\mathsf{sSet}sSet, or sSet≤1\mathsf{sSet}_{\leq 1}sSet≤1​, the terminal object again has just two subobjects.
Thanks!
Hi, does anyone has recommendation to understand cohomology structure of information? I think I need to start from the most basic definitions and go from there.

Does the inclusion sSet≤k→sSet\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}\to \mathbf{sSet}sSet≤k​→sSet have a left adjoint? Its right adjoint is given by kkk-truncation (as discussed above), so sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}sSet≤k​ is coreflective in sSet\mathbf{sSet}sSet. I wonder whether it is also reflective.

There's room for confusion here, since there are two canonical functors sSet≤k→sSet\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}\to \mathbf{sSet}sSet≤k​→sSet, the two adjoints of the kkk-truncation functor sSet→sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet}\to \mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}sSet→sSet≤k​ discussed above; since you specify that you're interested in the left adjoint to the truncation, you're talking about the inclusion of kkk-skeletal simplicial sets.

The inclusion of kkk-simplicial sets fails to preserve products, since products of simplicial sets tend to have non-degenerate higher-dimensional simplices. Is that enough of a hint? As such, it doesn't have a left adjoint.
with one exception, k=0k = 0k=0!

Thanks!

But there's actually no room for confusion, because I said "the inclusion". sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}sSet≤k​ is a (full) subcategory of sSet\mathbf{sSet}sSet, and hence there's only one canonical embedding sSet≤k→sSet\mathbf{sSet}_{\leq k}\to\mathbf{sSet}sSet≤k​→sSet.

Well this is a matter of what definitions you use. sSet\mathbf{sSet}sSet is the category of presheaves on a category Δ\DeltaΔ, sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet}_{\le k}sSet≤k​ is the category of presheaves on a full subcategory Δ≤k⊆Δ\Delta_{\le k} \subseteq \DeltaΔ≤k​⊆Δ. The "obvious" functor then is the restriction functor sSet→sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet} \to \mathbf{sSet}_{\le k}sSet→sSet≤k​ which takes a functor on Δ\DeltaΔ and restricts it to Δ≤k\Delta_{\le k}Δ≤k​. Any functor of this type has both left and right adjoints. In this particular case, both the left and right adjoints are fully faithful, so they are equivalences between sSet≤k\mathbf{sSet}_{\le k}sSet≤k​ and full subcategories of sSet\mathbf{sSet}sSet--but two different subcategories!
Based on your other comments, you must have the left adjoint in mind.

The two adjoints here give the "skeleton" (left adjoint) and "coskeleton" (right adjoint) of a truncated simplicial set:

The nnn-skeleton produces a simplicial set that is freely filled with degenerate simplices above degree nnn. Conversely, the nnn-coskeleton produces a simplicial set having a simplex of degree m>nm \gt nm>n whenever there is a compatible family of mmm-faces.

In simple terms, the skeleton leaves holes, while the coskeleton fills them in.

John Baez said:

Yes, it looks like their nasty definition of "morphism between graphs" is the price they pay for not working with reflexive graphs.

Yes, I agree that this definition is pretty nasty. I found a more conceptual way of explaining the equivalence in Kerodon.001N: observe that the usual "category of directed graphs" (the category of presheaves on ∙⇉∙\bullet\rightrightarrows\bullet∙⇉∙) can be considered as a coreflective subcategory of the category of semisimplicial sets. This adjunction between directed graphs and semisimplicial sets can be composed with the Teixeira–Barton adjunction between semisimplicial sets and simplicial sets. One gets an adjunction F⊣UF\dashv UF⊣U between directed graphs and simplicial sets, which can be restricted to an adjunction F′⊣U′F'\dashv U'F′⊣U′ between directed graphs and simplicial sets of dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1, since all simplicial sets in the image of FFF have dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1. This adjunction F′⊣U′F'\dashv U'F′⊣U′ induces a monad U′F′U'F'U′F′, whose Kleisli category is the category of directed graphs and "nasty" graph morphisms. Since F′F'F′ is essentially surjective, this category is equivalent to the category of simplicial sets of dimension ≤1\leq 1≤1.
